description.narrative: Insatsen avser att stärka och skydda mänskliga rättigheter i Burma, genom kapacitetsutveckling av Burmas National Human Rights Commission och andra relevanta MRaktörer , genomfört av Raoul Wallenberg Insititutet (RWI)

Thisintervention aim at strengthening the capacity of the MNHRC, and its key partners, to more effectively implement their mandates to promote and protect human rights in Burma. The capacity building support is provided by the Raoul Wallenberg Institute. The support includes building capacity and developing knowledge within th

Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: At output level, some of the key results reported by RWI included: - Increased knowledge and skills among MNHRC staff and commissioners as regards: human rights, including human rights of women; tools and procedures for the effective management and operation of MNHRC; the exercise of functional capacities of MNHRC. - Increased knowledge and skills among partner academic institutions to design and deliver high quality human rights education, including non-discrimination, equality and human rights of women - Improved knowledge on human rights research methodologies among partner academic institutions. - Increased opportunities for outreach and networking as well as participation in international research forums for human rights academics in Myanmar. - Identified areas of cooperation between MNHRC and government and CSO stakeholders. On outcome level, some of the results reported by RWI are: Over the years of the cooperation, the number of recommendations, statements, advice and reports issued by MNHRC on various human rights issues increased. This is likely due to the Commission growing as an organisation, but RWI argues that it also can be attributed to the cooperation with RWI. In general, statements issued by the Commission correctly identified the human rights issues at hand and proposed recommendations largely in line with international human rights law. While the Commission has called upon government to address some pertinent human rights issues (such as freedom of assembly, rights of priseners, inclusive participation in the peace process) it has still not gone far enough in calling for human rights to be respected in some cases deemed 'controversial'. MNHRC is now generally well known amongst the public and within the government as the officially mandated body to protect and promote human rights in the country. This is a result of the Commission's extensive outreach work. In summary, the picture is mixed when it comes to capacity improvements with MNHRC over the programme period. On the one hand, RWI reports that the Commission has developed substantially in all capacity dimensions (human rights, operational and functional) from the start of the programme, albeit from a very low starting point. On the other hand, important capacity gaps remain which in part relate to the legacies of Myanmar's past but also pose serious questions regarding MNHRC's credibility as an independent, national human rights institution that is equally addressing all issues of concern. Regarding the work with academic institutions, RWI reports that capacities have been strengthened. RWI has attempted to develop the technical knowledge in parallel with providing two universities with human rights in the curricula. Institutional capacities have been addressed by strengthening the role of academia to be a platform for debate on human rights and strengthening human rights promoting activities. This has been done mainly by promoting the universities' outreach function and relationship with other institutions relevant for human rights promotion.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
